title: August Jobs Report Will Keep Fed on Track to Cut Rates
text:
The August jobs report is likely to keep the Federal Reserve on track to lower its benchmark interest rate by a quarter-percentage point in two weeks to cushion the U.S. economy amid signs of slowing growth.

Concerns about a deteriorating outlook for the global expansion and the U.S.-China trade war, which are creating uncertainty for businesses that could chill investment and hiring, animated the Fed’s decision to cut rates in July and will do so again this month.

For the Fed, the U.S. employment report likely doesn’t provide a strong signal that the economy is deteriorating markedly. Neither should it deliver the “all-clear” sign that the economy is immune to a global manufacturing slowdown and declining business investment, which suggests the Fed will keep the door open to a third rate cut later this fall following its September meeting.

The unemployment rate held steady at 3.7% in August. Employers added 130,000 jobs, though that included 25,000 temporary government hires for the coming census count. The share of Americans who had a job also rose.

Video

For the Fed and economic forecasters, it is a tale of two economies right now. The manufacturing sector, which is a small and shrinking share of U.S. output, has been contracting. It is especially exposed to the trade war and uncertainty about any potential escalation of trade hostilities because of how international supply chains have been built over a generation.

The much bigger services sector of the U.S. economy has been in better shape, underpinned by robust consumer spending. Evidence that hiring is slowing down to levels that would boost the unemployment rate would be a significant concern for the Fed because such a pullback would mean less income for consumers, threatening the economy’s primary growth engine.

A related worry is that trade policy uncertainty has already chilled business investment. If businesses look to cut their costs further, they could stop hiring workers or even lay them off.

Market-determined interest rates have been falling this summer, reflecting investors’ concerns about long-term growth prospects. Fed officials have framed quarter-point rate cuts as a way to take out an insurance policy against a potentially deeper slowdown. They lowered their rate in July to a range between 2% and 2.25%.

One challenge for the Fed in reading the jobs numbers is that officials for years have expected that, as the current economic expansion matures, the rate of monthly hiring should slow. That is precisely what has been happening this year.

For example, the private sector has added 129,000 jobs per month over the past three months, on average. That is down from 236,000 jobs per month, on average, over the three months ended December.

If employers were running out of workers to hire, it is possible this would be reflected in rising wages. But wage growth hasn’t accelerated significantly this year. Average hourly earnings were up 3.2% over the year ended August, down from a 3.4% increase in February.

The report also follows revisions to data on U.S. corporate profits and employment that have suggested the economy was on a slightly slower track last year than previously thought.

A few indicators are receiving extra attention from economists, Fed officials, and others looking for any early alarms about a slowdown. Weekly hours worked have declined this year even though the unemployment rate has held steady and at historically low levels. Businesses tend to cut back workers’ hours before cutting back on hiring entirely.

An index of aggregate weekly hours of private-sector nonsupervisory workers rose 0.8% from a year ago in August, down from a rise of 2.5% one year ago but up from a 0.7% increase in July.

The report showed continued evidence of a slowdown in the manufacturing sector, too. Overtime hours worked in that sector fell nearly 9% from a year ago, the largest such decline since 2015, when a large drop in oil prices led to cutbacks across the U.S. energy production sector.

Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is set to speak on the economic outlook at a moderated discussion in Zurich at 12:30 p.m. ET on Friday.

President Trump has been pressuring the Fed and Mr. Powell to cut interest rates more aggressively. Mr. Trump selected Mr. Powell to lead the central bank for a four-year term that began last year.

“They were WAY too early to raise [rates], and Way too late to cut,” Mr. Trump said on Twitter on Friday morning, minutes before the release of the jobs report. “Where did I find this guy Jerome? Oh well, you can’t win them all.”

Write to Nick Timiraos at nick.timiraos@wsj.com
